1. Verify you're logged into a LogicMonitor portal 2. Check that a portal is selected in the Context dropdown 3. Try selecting different module type filters 4. Refresh the browser with F5
1. Clear all search filters 2. Ensure all module types are enabled 3. Verify the module exists in **Settings LogicModules** 4. The module may be in a different portal
Some modules don't have traditional scripts: - SNMP-based modules may only have OID configurations - Some modules use DataSource Templates - Check if the script is in a different section (AD vs Collection)
--- ## Best Practices Use descriptive tab names when loading multiple scripts. Save local copies before making major changes. Load the AD script first to understand instance discovery. Test with the same device the module targets. Load Edit Test with Run Script Verify parsed output Commit changes back to the portal. --- ## Next Steps
Frequently asked questions about LMDA Composer.

Answers to common questions about LMDA Composer.

## General Questions

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="What is LMDA Composer?" icon="information">
    LMDA Composer is a Chrome extension that provides a focused workspace for developing and testing LogicMonitor scripts. It offers features like:

    - Monaco-powered code editor
    - Script execution on collectors
    - Output parsing and validation
    - LogicModule browsing and management
    - API Explorer
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Is it free?" icon="star">
    **Yes!** LMDA Composer is completely free. It's a community project created to help LogicMonitor users be more productive. Open source release is planned for the future.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Is it affiliated with LogicMonitor?" icon="information">
    **No.** LMDA Composer is an independent community project. It is not affiliated with, endorsed by, or officially connected to LogicMonitor, Inc. LogicMonitor is a registered trademark of LogicMonitor, Inc.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Browser Support

<CardGrid>
  <FeatureCard title="Chrome" icon="globe" color="green">
    <Badge text="Recommended" variant="success" />
    Full support for all features.
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="Edge" icon="globe" color="green">
    <Badge text="Full Support" variant="success" />
    Same capabilities as Chrome.
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="Brave" icon="shield" color="orange">
    <Badge text="With Limitations" variant="note" />
    May need to enable File System Access API.
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="Firefox / Safari" icon="globe" color="red">
    <Badge text="Not Supported" variant="caution" />
    Extension API limitations prevent support.
  </FeatureCard>
</CardGrid>

---

## Installation

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="How do I install?" icon="rocket">
    Install from the Chrome Web Store for the easiest setup with automatic updates.

    <LinkCard
      title="Installation Guide"
      description="Detailed installation instructions."
      href="/lmda-composer/getting-started/installation/"
    />
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Why these permissions?" icon="setting">
    LMDA Composer requires permissions to:
    - **Access LogicMonitor tabs**: Use your existing session
    - **Store data locally**: Settings, history, drafts
    - **Access the file system**: Opening/saving files
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Multiple portals?" icon="list-format">
    **Yes!** Log into each portal in separate browser tabs, and LMDA Composer will detect all active sessions. Switch between portals using the Context dropdown.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Script Execution

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Why can't I run my script?" icon="warning">
    Common reasons:
    - No portal selected
    - No collector selected
    - Collector is offline
    - Another execution is in progress

    <LinkCard
      title="Troubleshooting"
      description="Detailed solutions for common issues."
      href="/lmda-composer/reference/troubleshooting/"
    />
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Which collectors can I use?" icon="rocket">
    You can run scripts on any collector you have access to in LogicMonitor. The collector must be online and able to communicate with LogicMonitor.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Character limit?" icon="document">
    **Yes**, LogicMonitor has a 64,000 character limit for scripts. LMDA Composer shows a warning when you approach this limit.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="PowerShell on Linux?" icon="close">
    **No.** PowerShell scripts can only execute on Windows collectors. If you select a Linux collector with a PowerShell script, you'll see an error.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

### Execution Modes

| Mode | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| <Badge text="Freeform" variant="default" /> | General scripting, no output validation |
| <Badge text="Active Discovery" variant="note" /> | Testing AD scripts with instance output parsing |
| <Badge text="Collection" variant="success" /> | Testing collection scripts with datapoint validation |
| <Badge text="Batch Collection" variant="tip" /> | Testing batch scripts with multi-instance output |

---

## Editor

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Custom themes?" icon="sun">
    Currently, LMDA Composer supports System (auto), Light, and Dark themes. Custom themes are not yet supported.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Other languages?" icon="seti:groovy">
    **No.** LMDA Composer is specifically designed for LogicMonitor scripting, which uses Groovy and PowerShell.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Import VS Code settings?" icon="setting">
    Not currently. LMDA Composer has its own settings that can be configured in the Settings dialog.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Autocomplete?" icon="pencil">
    LMDA Composer doesn't currently provide LogicMonitor-specific autocomplete. Monaco provides basic language autocomplete for Groovy and PowerShell syntax.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Files and Saving

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Where are scripts saved?" icon="seti:folder">
    This depends on how you're working:
    - **Local files**: Saved to your computer's file system
    - **Module scripts**: Saved to LogicMonitor when you commit
    - **Drafts**: Automatically saved to browser storage
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Unsaved changes?" icon="warning">
    LMDA Composer auto-saves drafts. When you reopen, it offers to restore unsaved work. However, it's best practice to save regularly.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Sync across devices?" icon="rocket">
    LMDA Composer doesn't have built-in sync. You can:
    - Save files to cloud-synced folders (Dropbox, OneDrive, etc.)
    - Use version control (Git)
    - Module scripts are synced via LogicMonitor
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## API Explorer

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Need API tokens?" icon="seti:json">
    **No!** Like script execution, the API Explorer uses your active browser session. No separate API credentials needed.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="What operations?" icon="list-format">
    You can perform any LogicMonitor API operation that your user account has permission for, including GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE requests.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Rate limits?" icon="warning">
    **Yes**, LogicMonitor's standard API rate limits apply. You'll see a 429 error if you exceed limits.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Module Management

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Create new modules?" icon="add-document">
    Currently, LMDA Composer is focused on editing existing modules. You can:
    - Import modules from LogicModule Exchange
    - Edit scripts in existing modules
    - Commit changes back to LogicMonitor

    Creating entirely new modules should be done in the LogicMonitor UI.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="What happens when I commit?" icon="approve-check-circle">
    When you commit:
    1. Your script changes are pushed to LogicMonitor
    2. Any staged metadata changes are applied
    3. The module is updated in your portal immediately
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Revert to previous version?" icon="history">
    There is no built-in version history for user changes. To protect your work:
    - Export scripts to local files before major changes
    - Use Git for version control of exported scripts
    - For Exchange modules, Lineage shows the original LM versions (not your edits)
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Snippets and History

<CardGrid>
  <FeatureCard title="Share snippets with team?" icon="users" color="purple">
    Snippets are stored locally in your browser. To share:
    - Export snippet content manually
    - Include in team documentation
    - Add to shared code repositories
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="How long is history kept?" icon="history" color="blue">
    History is kept until you manually clear it, the configured limit is reached (oldest removed), or browser storage is cleared.
    
    Default limit is **50** entries, configurable in Settings.
  </FeatureCard>
</CardGrid>

---

## Security

<CardGrid>
  <FeatureCard title="Is my data secure?" icon="shield" color="green">
    - Runs entirely in your browser
    - No data sent to third-party servers
    - All communication is with LogicMonitor using your session
    - Local storage is limited to your browser
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="Can others see my scripts?" icon="lock" color="blue">
    Scripts in local files are only on your computer. Scripts in LogicModules follow your LogicMonitor access controls.
  </FeatureCard>
</CardGrid>

### What data is stored locally?

- Settings and preferences
- Execution history
- Snippets
- Draft files
- Recent file list
- API request history

---

## Updates and Support

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="How do I get updates?" icon="rocket">
    If installed from Chrome Web Store, updates are automatic.
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Report bugs?" icon="alert-triangle">
    Report issues through the LogicMonitor community channels. Include:
    - Steps to reproduce
    - Expected vs. actual behavior
    - Browser and OS version
    - Screenshots if helpful
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Contribute?" icon="star">
    LMDA Composer is not yet open source, but we're working on it! Once the source code is publicly available, you'll be able to:
    - Report bugs via GitHub
    - Suggest features
    - Submit pull requests
    - Help with documentation

    Stay tuned for the open source release.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Get Help

<CardGrid>
  <FeatureCard title="Documentation" icon="book" color="blue">
    You're here! Browse the full documentation.
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="LogicMonitor Community" icon="users" color="green">
    Connect with other LM users and ask questions.
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="Open Source Soon" icon="clock" color="purple">
    GitHub Issues and Discussions will be available once the project goes open source.
  </FeatureCard>
</CardGrid>

Solutions for common issues with LMDA Composer.

import { CardGrid, Steps, Tabs, TabItem, Aside, Badge, LinkCard } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';
import StatusBadge from '../../../components/StatusBadge.astro';
import FeatureCard from '../../../components/FeatureCard.astro';

This guide covers common issues you might encounter with LMDA Composer and how to resolve them.

## Connection Issues

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="No Portals Detected" icon="warning">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Portal dropdown is empty
    - "No portals found" message

    **Solutions:**

    <Steps>

    1. **Log into LogicMonitor**  
       Open a new tab, navigate to your LogicMonitor portal, and log in with your credentials.

    2. **Wait for full load**  
       Ensure the LogicMonitor dashboard fully loads (not just the login page).

    3. **Return to LMDA Composer**  
       Click refresh in the Context dropdown.

    4. **Multiple Portals**  
       Each portal needs its own logged-in tab. Open separate tabs for each portal.

    </Steps>

    <Aside type="tip">
      Some browsers block cross-tab communication. Try Chrome if using another browser.
    </Aside>
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Session Expired" icon="close">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Portal shows <StatusBadge status="error" label="Offline" />
    - Scripts fail with 401 errors
    - "Unauthorized" messages

    **Solutions:**

    <Steps>

    1. Open the LogicMonitor tab

    2. Log in again if prompted

    3. Return to LMDA Composer

    4. Click refresh in Context dropdown

    </Steps>

    <Aside type="note">
      LogicMonitor sessions expire after inactivity. Keep the LM tab active or re-login periodically.
    </Aside>
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Collector Offline" icon="rocket">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Collector shows offline status
    - Cannot select the collector
    - Scripts can't execute

    **Solutions:**

    <Steps>

    1. **Verify in LogicMonitor**  
       Check collector status in Settings  Collectors

    2. **Restart Collector**  
       On the collector server, restart the collector service

    3. **Check Network**  
       Verify the collector can reach LogicMonitor and check firewall rules

    </Steps>
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Script Execution Issues

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Script Won't Run" icon="warning">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Run button doesn't respond
    - No output appears
    - Execution never starts

    **Solutions:**

    <CardGrid>
      <FeatureCard title="Check Context" icon="settings" color="blue">
        Ensure portal is selected, collector is selected, and collector is online.
      </FeatureCard>
      <FeatureCard title="Check for Running Execution" icon="play" color="green">
        Only one execution at a time. Cancel current execution first. Look for spinner on Run button.
      </FeatureCard>
      <FeatureCard title="Script Errors" icon="warning" color="orange">
        Check for syntax errors. Validate script compiles. Review error messages.
      </FeatureCard>
    </CardGrid>
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Script Times Out" icon="rocket">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Execution runs too long
    - <StatusBadge status="timeout" label="Timeout" /> error appears
    - Partial output visible

    **Solutions:**

    <Steps>

    1. **Optimize Script**  
       Reduce execution time, add efficient queries, avoid infinite loops

    2. **Check Target Device**  
       Device may be slow to respond, network latency, or overloaded

    3. **Simplify for Testing**  
       Test smaller portions, use fewer iterations, add debug output

    </Steps>
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="PowerShell on Linux" icon="close">
    **Symptoms:**
    - PowerShell script fails
    - Error about script type
    - Collector compatibility warning

    **Solution:**

    <Aside type="caution">
      PowerShell scripts only run on Windows collectors. Select a Windows collector or convert your script to Groovy.
    </Aside>
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Editor Issues

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Editor Not Loading" icon="warning">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Editor area is blank
    - No syntax highlighting
    - Can't type in editor

    **Solutions:**

    <Steps>

    1. **Refresh the Page**  
       Press <kbd>F5</kbd> or <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>R</kbd>

    2. **Clear Browser Cache**  
       Settings  Clear browsing data  Clear cached files

    3. **Check Extensions**  
       Other browser extensions may conflictdisable and test

    </Steps>
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Wrong Syntax Highlighting" icon="pencil">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Colors don't match language
    - Keywords not highlighted
    - Editor confused

    **Solutions:**

    1. **Check Language Setting**  
       Verify Groovy/PowerShell toggle is correct

    2. **File Extension**  
       Opening `.ps1` should set PowerShell  
       Opening `.groovy` should set Groovy

    3. **Switch and Switch Back**  
       Toggle the language setting to refresh
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## File System Issues

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Can't Save Files" icon="warning">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Save triggers download instead
    - "Permission denied" errors
    - Save dialog every time

    **Solutions:**

    <Steps>

    1. **Grant Permissions**  
       Browser may need file access permission. Click "Allow" when prompted. Choose "Edit" not "View".

    2. **Brave Browser**  
       May require enabling File System Access API in `brave://flags`

    3. **Vivaldi Browser**  
       May require enabling File System Access API in `vivaldi://extensions`

    </Steps>
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="File Handle Lost" icon="close">
    **Symptoms:**
    - "File no longer available"
    - Can't save to original location
    - Need to Save As

    **Solutions:**

    1. **Reconnect File**  
       Use Save As to re-establish handle, select the same file

    2. **File Was Moved**  
       Locate file in new location and open again
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Drafts Not Recovering" icon="history">
    **Symptoms:**
    - No draft recovery prompt
    - Lost unsaved work
    - Drafts seem missing

    **Solutions:**

    1. **Check Browser Storage**  
       Storage may be fullclear some browser data

    2. **Same Browser Required**  
       Drafts are per-browser. Use the same browser where you worked.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## API Explorer Issues

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Request Fails" icon="warning">
    **Symptoms:**
    - 400/401/403/500 errors
    - Request doesn't complete
    - Unexpected error messages

    **Solutions:**

    <CardGrid>
      <FeatureCard title="Check Endpoint Path" icon="braces" color="blue">
        Verify path is correct. Include required path parameters. Check LogicMonitor API docs.
      </FeatureCard>
      <FeatureCard title="Check Request Body" icon="document" color="purple">
        Validate JSON syntax. Include required fields. Check data types.
      </FeatureCard>
      <FeatureCard title="Check Permissions" icon="lock" color="red">
        403 means insufficient permissions. Verify your user role. Contact admin if needed.
      </FeatureCard>
      <FeatureCard title="Rate Limiting" icon="clock" color="orange">
        429 means rate limited. Wait before retrying. Reduce request frequency.
      </FeatureCard>
    </CardGrid>
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Response Not Displaying" icon="document">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Response area blank
    - JSON not formatted
    - Truncated response

    **Solutions:**

    1. **Large Response**  
       Very large responses may truncate. Increase response limit in Settings. Use `fields` parameter to reduce size.

    2. **Invalid JSON**  
       Some endpoints return non-JSON. Check Content-Type header.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Module Operations

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="Can't Commit Changes" icon="warning">
    **Symptoms:**
    - Commit button disabled
    - Commit fails with error
    - Changes not saved to LM

    **Solutions:**

    <Steps>

    1. **Check Module Binding**  
       Tab must be bound to a module. Local files can't commit. Look for link icon on tab.

    2. **Check Portal Match**  
       Active portal must match bound portal. Switch portals if needed.

    3. **Check Permissions**  
       Need write access to the module. Verify role in LogicMonitor.

    4. **Validation Errors**  
       Check for error messages. Fix issues before committing.

    </Steps>
  </TabItem>
  
  <TabItem label="Module Not Found" icon="close">
    **Symptoms:**
    - "Module not found" error
    - Can't load module script
    - Browser shows empty list

    **Solutions:**

    1. **Check Portal**  
       Ensure correct portal is selected. Module may be in different portal.

    2. **Module Deleted**  
       Module may have been removed. Check in LogicMonitor.

    3. **Permissions**  
       May not have access to the module. Check with administrator.
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

---

## Performance Issues

<CardGrid>
  <FeatureCard title="Slow Performance" icon="zap" color="orange">
    **Symptoms:** Typing lag, slow scrolling, delayed responses

    **Solutions:**
    - Large files may be slowsplit into smaller files
    - Close unused tabs
    - Close other browser tabs
    - Disable Minimap in Settings
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="High Memory Usage" icon="warning" color="red">
    **Symptoms:** Browser using lots of RAM, system slowdown

    **Solutions:**
    - Each tab uses memoryclose when done
    - Clear large history
    - Refresh page periodically (save work first)
  </FeatureCard>
</CardGrid>

---

## Getting Help

<CardGrid>
  <FeatureCard title="Report a Bug" icon="alert-triangle" color="orange">
    1. Note the steps to reproduce
    2. Check browser console for errors (<kbd>F12</kbd>)
    3. Report via LogicMonitor community channels
    4. Include browser and OS version
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="Community Support" icon="users" color="purple">
    Connect with other LogicMonitor users in the community forums for questions and solutions.
  </FeatureCard>
  <FeatureCard title="Check for Updates" icon="refresh-cw" color="blue">
    Ensure you're running the latest version. Check extension version in Settings. Updates are automatic from the Chrome Web Store.
  </FeatureCard>
</CardGrid>

---

import { CardGrid, Steps, Tabs, TabItem, Aside, Badge, LinkCard } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Icon } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import FeatureCard from '../../../components/FeatureCard.astro'; This page documents the release history of LMDA Composer. Each release includes new features, improvements, and bug fixes. ## Version Numbering LMDA Composer follows semantic versioning (SemVer):
Breaking changes or significant new features
New features, backward compatible
Bug fixes and minor improvements
--- ## v1.3.5 Initial Public Release
January 2026
LMDA Composer is now available for LogicMonitor power users! This release includes a comprehensive set of features for LogicModule development. ### Script Editor Full-featured code editor with syntax highlighting for Groovy and PowerShell. Code folding, find and replace, multiple cursors, line numbers. Automatic draft saving for crash recovery. ### Script Execution Run scripts on any connected collector with real-time output streaming. Freeform, Active Discovery, Collection, and Batch Collection modes. Parsed output for AD and Collection modes with validation. ### Portal Tools Browse and import scripts from your portal. Filter by module type and navigate the module hierarchy. Search across all module scripts, datapoints, and metadata. Find code patterns across your entire portal. Test and validate AppliesTo expressions. See exactly which resources match your expression. Run collector debug commands with formatted results. Includes comprehensive health check reports. ### API Explorer Uses your browser sessionno API tokens needed. Browse and search available LogicMonitor API endpoints. Build requests with query parameters, headers, and body. Formatted JSON responses with syntax highlighting. ### Module Management Edit module metadata including name, description, AppliesTo, and more. View Exchange release history for LogicMonitor core modules. Push script and metadata changes back to LogicMonitor. ### Workspace Features Work with multiple scripts simultaneously. Module binding indicators on tabs. Open, save, and manage local script files with File System Access API. Built-in and custom code snippets for rapid development. Track past executions with script replay capability. ### User Experience Quick actions to get startednew file, open file, import module. Keyboard-driven workflow with Ctrl+Shift+P. Comprehensive shortcuts for power users. Theme, font size, editor preferences, and more. ### Browser Support | Browser | Support | |---------|---------| | Chrome | | | Edge | | | Brave | | ### Known Limitations
- Extension not available in Firefox/Safari - PowerShell only runs on Windows collectors - Custom editor themes not yet supported
--- ## Contributing
LMDA Composer is not yet open source, but we're working on making it publicly available. Once released, contributions will be welcome!
Found an issue? Let us know via the feedback channels below. Have an idea? We'd love to hear your suggestions. Source code and contribution guidelines will be available once the project goes open source. --- ## Feedback We'd love to hear your feedback! If you have suggestions, find bugs, or want to share how you use LMDA Composer: - Share with the LogicMonitor community - Reach out through LogicMonitor community channels
Review past script executions and reload scripts.

import { Card, CardGrid, Steps, Tabs, TabItem, Aside, Badge, LinkCard } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Icon } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import StatusBadge from '../../../components/StatusBadge.astro'; import FeatureCard from '../../../components/FeatureCard.astro'; Execution History tracks every script you run in LMDA Composer, allowing you to review past executions and reload scripts. ## Accessing History Click **History** tab in the right sidebar. Ctrl+B to toggle sidebar. Press Ctrl+Shift+P and type "History". --- ## History Entry Details Each execution entry shows: | Field | Description | |-------|-------------| | Status | or | | Name | Tab or module name | | Timestamp | When it was executed | | Duration | How long it took | | Mode | Execution mode used | | Language | Groovy or PowerShell | | Collector | Which collector ran it | | Device | Target device (if set) | | Output Preview | First few lines of output | --- ## Viewing Full Details Click **View** on an entry to see: - Complete status and timing - Portal and collector info - Device context - Execution mode and language The complete script that was executed: - Syntax highlighted - Read-only view - Copy functionality Complete output from the execution: - Raw text output - Scroll for large outputs - Copy entire output For AD/Collection modes: - Parsed instance/datapoint data - Same format as Output Panel --- ## Reloading Scripts ### Load to Editor Click **Load** on a history entry to: 1. Open a new tab 2. Populate with the historical script 3. Set language and mode automatically 4. Ready for editing and re-running ### Portal Mismatch Warning If the history entry is from a different portal:
A warning dialog appears with options: - **Switch Portal**: Change to the original portal - **Load Anyway**: Load as freeform script - **Cancel**: Abort the load
### Module Binding Historical scripts from modules: - Can restore module binding if portal matches - Falls back to freeform if unavailable --- ## History Management ### History Limit Configure the maximum history entries: 1. Open Settings (Ctrl+,) 2. Find "History Size" 3. Set desired limit (10-500, default is **50**) 4. Oldest entries removed when limit exceeded ### Clearing History To clear all history: 1. Click **Clear** button in panel 2. Confirm the action 3. All entries removed permanently
Individual entries cannot be deleted separately. Use the clear function or let them naturally expire based on the history limit.
--- ## History Use Cases Find a working historical execution, compare with current script, identify what changed. If you lose script content, find the last execution and load it back. Compare execution durations across runs to identify slow executions. Track what was executed, check timestamps, document actions taken. --- ## What's Stored | Data | Stored? | |------|---------| | Script content | | | Output | | | Collector info | | | Device info | | | Timestamp | | | Duration | | | Tab/module name | | | Portal binding | | ### Storage Location History is stored: - In browser local storage - Per-browser (not synced) - Persists across sessions - Subject to size limits
Large outputs or many entries may impact browser storage. Very large histories may trigger automatic cleanup.
--- ## History Panel Actions | Action | Icon | Description | |--------|------|-------------| | View | Eye | See full execution details | | Load | Arrow | Load script to editor | | Copy | Clipboard | Copy script content | --- ## Best Practices Periodically review history, export important scripts, document significant executions. Review important entries and save scripts you want to keep before clearing. Review successful patterns and past decisions to improve future scripts. --- ## Privacy Considerations History may contain: - Device information - Property values (from token substitution) - API responses (if printed) - Sensitive configuration data Clear history when: - Switching between projects - Working on sensitive systems - Sharing the browser/computer --- ## Next Steps
Opening, saving, and managing local script files.

import { Card, CardGrid, Steps, Tabs, TabItem, Aside, Badge, LinkCard } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Icon } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import StatusBadge from '../../../components/StatusBadge.astro'; import FeatureCard from '../../../components/FeatureCard.astro'; LMDA Composer supports working with local files on your computer, allowing you to develop scripts outside of LogicModules and manage your own script library. ## File Types ### Supported Extensions
Groovy scripts
PowerShell scripts
Plain text (uses tab language setting)
When you open a file, the extension determines the language, syntax highlighting applies automatically, and execution mode defaults to Freeform. --- ## Opening Files Click **Open File** and select from the system dialog. Press Ctrl+O / Cmd+O. Drag a file onto the LMDA Composer window. Click a file from the recent files list on the welcome screen. --- ## Creating New Files 1. Click **New File** on welcome screen, or click **+** in the tab bar, or press Ctrl+N 2. File opens with your default language setting 3. Start writing your script (or insert a template from Snippets) 4. Save with Ctrl+S when ready --- ## Saving Files **Keyboard:** Ctrl+S / Cmd+S **First save:** Opens a dialog to choose location and filename. **Subsequent saves:** File updates in place, no dialog appears, dirty indicator clears. **Keyboard:** Ctrl+Shift+S / Cmd+Shift+S Creates a copy at a new location. Original file remains unchanged. --- ## File System Access API LMDA Composer uses the modern File System Access API for seamless file operations. ### Browser Compatibility Direct file reading/writing, file handles persist across sessions. Same capabilities as Chrome. May need to enable the File System Access API flag. ### Brave Browser Setup If File System Access is not available in Brave: 1. Open `brave://flags` in a new tab 2. Search for "File System Access API" 3. Set it to **Enabled** 4. Restart your browser ### Vivaldi Setup For Vivaldi browser: 1. Open `vivaldi://extensions` 2. Select "LMDA Composer" 3. Enable "Allow access to file URLs" --- ## Auto-Save Drafts LMDA Composer automatically saves drafts to protect your work. Drafts saved every 30 seconds to browser local storage. Recovered on next session. If browser closes unexpectedly, draft recovery dialog appears on next open. Click **Restore** or **Discard**.
- Only unsaved changes are drafted - Very large files may not draft completely - Drafts are per-browser, not synced across devices
--- ## File Handles ### Persistent Handles For supported browsers: - File handles saved to session - Reopening restores handles - Continue editing from where you left off ### Handle Expiration Handles expire when: - Browser is fully closed - Permissions are revoked - File is moved or deleted ### Refreshing Handles If a handle expires: 1. File shows as "Unconnected" 2. Click **Reconnect** in tab 3. Select the file again --- ## Tabs and Files - Local files show the filename - Unsaved files show "Untitled" - Module tabs show module name with link icon The dirty dot () indicates: - Unsaved changes to disk - Modified since last save - Will prompt on close Closing a dirty tab shows options: - **Save & Close** - **Discard** - **Cancel** --- ## Recent Files ### Viewing Recent Files The welcome screen shows recent files with: - File name and path - Last opened date - Language indicator ### Managing Recent Files - Click to open a recent file - Right-click to remove from list - List auto-cleans invalid entries ### Recent Files Limit Configure in Settings: - Default: 10 files - Range: 5-50 files --- ## Best Practices Create a folder structure like `scripts/production/datasources/` for easy navigation. Save to cloud-synced folders (Dropbox, OneDrive) or use version control (Git). Use clear names like `DS_Linux_CPU_Usage.groovy` or `PS_Windows_Services.ps1`. ### Local Development Workflow 1. Create local file 2. Develop and test script 3. When ready, copy to module or import as new 4. Keep local copy as backup --- ## Next Steps
Configure LMDA Composer appearance, defaults, and behavior.

import { Card, CardGrid, Steps, Tabs, TabItem, Aside, Badge, LinkCard } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Icon } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import FeatureCard from '../../../components/FeatureCard.astro'; The Settings dialog lets you customize LMDA Composer to match your preferences and workflow. ## Opening Settings Ctrl+, / Cmd+, Press Ctrl+Shift+P and type "Settings". Actions Settings --- ## Settings Categories ### Theme | Option | Description | |--------|-------------| | | Follow OS light/dark setting | | | Always use light theme | | | Always use dark theme | The theme applies immediately when changed. ### Default Language Choose the language for new files: - **Groovy** (default) - **PowerShell** ### Default Mode Choose the execution mode for new files: - **Freeform** (default) - **Active Discovery** - **Collection** - **Batch Collection** ### Font Size - Range: 10px to 24px - Default: **14px** - Changes apply to all tabs ### Tab Size - Range: 2 to 8 spaces - Default: **2 spaces** - Affects new indentation ### Word Wrap - **On** (default): Lines wrap within viewport - **Off**: Horizontal scroll for long lines ### Minimap - **Show**: Display minimap on right for quick navigation - **Hide** (default): No minimap, more editor space ### History Size Maximum execution history entries to keep: - Range: 10 to 500 - Default: **50** - Oldest entries removed when exceeded ### API History Limit Maximum API requests to store: - Range: 10 to 200 - Default: **10** ### Response Size Limit Maximum response size to display: - Default: **250,000 bytes** (~250KB) - Larger responses truncated for performance - Full response still available via copy --- ## Default Values Summary | Setting | Default | |---------|---------| | Theme | System | | Default Language | Groovy | | Default Mode | Freeform | | Font Size | 14px | | Tab Size | 2 spaces | | Word Wrap | On | | Minimap | Hidden | | History Size | 50 | | API History Limit | 10 | | Response Size Limit | 250KB | --- ## Applying Settings ### Immediate Changes Most settings apply immediately: - Theme changes instantly - Font size updates all tabs - No refresh required ### New File Settings Some settings affect only new files: - Default language - Default mode - Tab size for new indentation Existing tabs keep their current settings. --- ## Resetting to Defaults 1. Scroll to bottom of Settings dialog 2. Click **Reset to Defaults** 3. Confirm the action 4. All settings restored to defaults
Reset cannot be undone. Note your custom settings before resetting.
--- ## Settings Storage ### Where Settings Are Stored Settings persist in: - Browser local storage - Per-browser (not synced) - Survive browser restarts ### Clearing Settings Settings are cleared when: - You reset to defaults - Browser data is cleared - Extension is uninstalled/reinstalled --- ## Recommended Settings For large/high-resolution displays: - **Font Size**: 16-18px - **Minimap**: Show - **Word Wrap**: Off For laptops or smaller screens: - **Font Size**: 12-14px - **Minimap**: Hide - **Word Wrap**: On For PowerShell development: - **Default Language**: PowerShell - **Tab Size**: 4 (PowerShell convention) For rapid script testing: - **Default Mode**: Freeform - **History Size**: 200+ (keep more history) --- ## Keyboard Shortcuts in Settings While in Settings dialog: | Key | Action | |-----|--------| | Escape | Close dialog | | Tab | Move to next field | | Enter | Apply selection | --- ## Settings vs. Tab State Configured in Settings dialog. Apply to all sessions, persist across restarts. Managed per tab: language selection, execution mode, script content. Temporary: open tabs, sidebar state, last used collector. --- ## Troubleshooting Settings Check browser storage isn't full. Verify extension has storage permission. Try clearing and re-setting. Refresh the page. Check OS theme setting. Try a specific theme instead of System. Check you're on a script tab. Try switching tabs. Reload the extension page. --- ## Next Steps
Use built-in and custom code snippets to speed up development.

import { Card, CardGrid, Steps, Tabs, TabItem, Aside, Badge, LinkCard } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Icon } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import FeatureCard from '../../../components/FeatureCard.astro'; The Snippets Library provides reusable code templates and patterns for common LogicMonitor scripting tasks. ## Accessing Snippets Click **Snippets** tab in the right sidebar. Press Ctrl+Shift+L / +Shift+L to open directly. Press Ctrl+Shift+P and type "Snippets". --- ## Snippet Types **Complete script starters** that replace your entire script content. Use templates when: - Starting a new script from scratch - Learning standard script patterns - Need a complete working example
Inserting a template replaces your current script content. A confirmation dialog appears.
**Code fragments** that insert at your cursor position. Use patterns when: - Adding functionality to an existing script - Inserting common boilerplate code - Using standard coding patterns Patterns are inserted without replacing existing content. --- ## Snippet Categories ### By Type
Complete script starters that replace your entire script
Code fragments that insert at cursor position
### By Language Snippets are language-specific: - **Groovy** snippets for Groovy scripts - **PowerShell** snippets for PowerShell scripts Use the filter to show only relevant snippets for your current language. ### By Source
Included with LMDA Composer
Your custom snippets
--- ## Using Built-in Snippets 1. Open the Snippets panel from the sidebar 2. Use filters to narrow by category, language, or type 3. Click a snippet to preview its full content 4. Click **Insert** to add the snippet to your editor --- ## Popular Built-in Snippets | Name | Description | |------|-------------| | **SNMP Walk** | Walk an SNMP OID tree and process results | | **HTTP API Collector** | Make HTTP API calls and parse JSON response | | **WMI Query Template** | Execute WMI queries on Windows devices | | **SSH Command Executor** | Run commands via SSH and collect output | | Name | Description | |------|-------------| | **SNMP Get Single** | Get a single SNMP OID value | | **JSON Response Parser** | Parse JSON and extract values | | **Try-Catch Block** | Error handling wrapper | | **AD Instance Line** | Format Active Discovery output | | **Collection Output** | Format key=value collection output | | Name | Description | |------|-------------| | **WMI Query** | Execute WMI queries | | **Registry Read** | Read Windows registry values | | **Service Status** | Check Windows service status | | **Performance Counter** | Read performance counters | --- ## Creating Custom Snippets 1. Click **Create Snippet** in the panel 2. Fill in required fields: - **Name**: Unique identifier - **Category**: Organization category - **Language**: Groovy or PowerShell - **Type**: Template or Pattern - **Content**: The actual code 3. Optionally add description and tags 4. Click **Save** ### Example Pattern ```groovy // SNMP Walk Pattern // TODO: Set target OID def baseOid = "1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1" def host = hostProps.get("system.hostname") def community = hostProps.get("snmp.community") def results = Snmp.walk(host, community, baseOid) results.each { oid, value -> println "${oid} = ${value}" } ``` --- ## Managing Custom Snippets Click the edit icon on your snippet, modify details, and save. Click the delete icon and confirm. Deleted snippets cannot be recovered.
Custom snippets are stored in browser local storage. They persist across sessions but are not synced between browsers/devices.
--- ## Snippet Organization ### Naming Conventions Use clear, descriptive names: - `SNMP_Walk_Interface_Stats` - `HTTP_GET_With_Auth` - `WMI_CPU_Query` ### Tags Add relevant tags for searchability: - **Technology**: `snmp`, `wmi`, `http` - **Purpose**: `discovery`, `collection` - **Module type**: `datasource`, `configsource` --- ## Best Practices If you write similar code often, generalize it with placeholders and save as a snippet. Periodically review, update outdated snippets, and remove unused ones. Include what it does, required variables, expected output, and limitations. Add `// TODO:` comments where users need to customize the code. --- ## Snippet Workflow Example Building a new DataSource: 1. Start with **Basic DataSource** template 2. Add **SNMP Walk** pattern for discovery 3. Add **Instance Output** pattern for AD formatting 4. Add **SNMP Get** pattern for collection 5. Customize for your specific use case --- ## Next Steps
Browse and import LogicMonitor's reusable code modules into your scripts.

import { Card, CardGrid, Steps, Tabs, TabItem, Aside, Badge, LinkCard, Code } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import { Icon } from '@astrojs/starlight/components'; import FeatureCard from '../../../components/FeatureCard.astro'; Module Snippets are LogicMonitor's library of reusable Groovy code modules. These modules provide helper functions for common tasks like data emission, debugging, API calls, and vendor-specific integrations. ## Accessing Module Snippets Press Ctrl+Shift+L / +Shift+L to open directly. Press Ctrl+Shift+P and type "Module Snippets". --- ## How It Works Module Snippets are fetched from your portal via a connected collector. The dialog displays all available modules grouped by category with full source code preview. 1. Open the Module Snippets dialog 2. Click **Fetch Module Snippets** to retrieve the list from your collector (first time only) 3. Browse categories or search for a specific module 4. Select a module to preview its full source code 5. Choose a version if multiple are available 6. Click **Insert Import** to add the loader boilerplate to your script --- ## Module Categories Modules are organized by vendor and functionality: | Category | Examples | Description | |----------|----------|-------------| | **LogicMonitor** | `lm.emit`, `lm.debug`, `lm.cache` | Core LM helpers for data emission, debugging, and caching | | **Cisco** | `cisco.meraki`, `cisco.aci` | Cisco Meraki, ACI, and network device integrations | | **VMware** | `vmware.vsphere` | vSphere, vCenter, and virtualization helpers | | **Aruba** | `aruba.*` | Aruba network device integrations | | **Palo Alto** | `paloalto.*` | Firewall and security integrations | | **NetApp** | `netapp.*` | Storage system integrations | | **Juniper** | `juniper.*` | Network device integrations | | **Protocols** | `proto.http`, `proto.snmp` | Protocol-specific helpers | | **Loader** | `loader.*` | Module loading utilities | --- ## The Import Boilerplate When you click **Insert Import**, LMDA Composer inserts the proper module loader boilerplate at your cursor position. This is the standard pattern for loading LogicMonitor modules: ```groovy /******************************************************************************* * Module Snippet: lm.emit ******************************************************************************/ import com.logicmonitor.common.sse.utils.GroovyScriptHelper as GSH import com.logicmonitor.mod.Snippets def modLoader = GSH.getInstance()._getScript("Snippets", Snippets.getLoader()).withBinding(getBinding()) def emit = modLoader.load("lm.emit", "1") ``` ### Understanding the Import | Component | Purpose | |-----------|---------| | `GroovyScriptHelper` | LogicMonitor's script execution helper | | `Snippets.getLoader()` | Retrieves the module loader from the collector | | `withBinding(getBinding())` | Passes the current script context to the module | | `modLoader.load(name, version)` | Loads the specified module at the given major version | ### Variable Naming The variable name is automatically derived from the module name: | Module Name | Variable | |-------------|----------| | `lm.emit` | `emit` | | `cisco.meraki` | `meraki` | | `proto.http` | `http` | | `lm.data.topo` | `topo` | --- ## Version Management Each module can have multiple versions available: Shown by default with a **latest** badge. Recommended for new scripts. Use the dropdown to select older versions for compatibility with existing scripts. The import uses the **major version** number only (e.g., `"1"` for version `1.3.0`).
The generated import uses the major version number, not the full version. This ensures your script gets the latest patch within that major version.
--- ## Source Code Preview The right panel shows the complete source code of the selected module: - **Full syntax highlighting** with Groovy support - **Copy button** to copy the entire source to clipboard - **Read-only editor** for browsing and searching within the code - **Version indicator** showing which version you're viewing
Previewing module source code is a great way to understand how LogicMonitor's official modules work. You can learn best practices and patterns directly from the implementation.
--- ## Caching Module Snippets uses intelligent caching to minimize collector requests: | Cache Type | Behavior | |------------|----------| | **Module List** | Cached after first fetch. Shows collector name and timestamp. | | **Source Code** | Cached per module+version when viewed. Shows green database icon. | ### Cache Indicators - **Green database icon** on a module = at least one version's source is cached - **Green database icon** on version = that specific version is cached locally - **Timestamp** in footer shows when the list was last fetched ### Refreshing Click the **Refresh** button next to the search box to fetch an updated module list from the collector. This is useful if new modules have been added to your portal. --- ## Using Loaded Modules Once a module is loaded, you can call its methods. Each module has its own APIpreview the source to see available functions. ### Example: Using lm.emit ```groovy // After loading the emit module def emit = modLoader.load("lm.emit", "1") // Use the emit helper to output datapoints emit.dataPoint("cpuUsage", 75.5) emit.dataPoint("memoryUsage", 82.3) ``` ### Example: Using cisco.meraki ```groovy // After loading the meraki module def meraki = modLoader.load("cisco.meraki", "1") // Use Meraki API helpers def orgs = meraki.getOrganizations(apiKey) orgs.each { org -> println "Organization: ${org.name}" } ``` --- ## Best Practices Start with the latest version unless you need specific compatibility with existing scripts. Preview the module source to understand its API before importing. The modLoader setup only needs to be included once per script, even if loading multiple modules. Periodically refresh the module list to see if newer versions are available. ### Loading Multiple Modules If you need multiple modules, include the loader setup once and call `load()` multiple times: ```groovy /******************************************************************************* * Module Snippets ******************************************************************************/ import com.logicmonitor.common.sse.utils.GroovyScriptHelper as GSH import com.logicmonitor.mod.Snippets def modLoader = GSH.getInstance()._getScript("Snippets", Snippets.getLoader()).withBinding(getBinding()) def emit = modLoader.load("lm.emit", "1") def http = modLoader.load("proto.http", "1") def cache = modLoader.load("lm.cache", "1") // Now use all three modules in your script ``` --- ## Next Steps
